Ano yon

There used to be a time when the powers-at-be were trying to convince people that Daniel Padilla was cool, casting him as the broody teenage bad-boy that had to be won over by the steely determination of his good-girl paramour Kathryn Bernardo. But he's not cool, at least in that way. He's got a big goofy smile, a friendly presence, and an earnestness that gives his characters surprising vulnerability. His growth as an actor largely involves him being comfortable up on screen, being some version of himself that's closer to who he really is.And this leads to the best bits of this movie, which almost seem to happen in a vacuum of narrative. It doesn't matter what came before or what might happen after. In the moment, it just looks like these two kids are enjoying themselves. Kathryn Bernardo hasn't quite kept up with Padilla's development, her performances getting a little stiffer as she gets older, but their clear affection for one another smooths out a lot of these scenes.But these moments don't actually exist in a vacuum. There's a movie around it, and like so many local big romcoms, there are just too many things going on. All the classic formula markers are there, too: some sort of medical problem, some parental issues and a whole bunch of characters that exist purely to tell the leads what they're supposed to be feeling. The movie stretches into two hours with the added weight of these rote elements, and by the time they fly off to some foreign land, it kind of feels like an entirely different movie. It shifts focus completely, and starts filling in even more backstory through yet another character that just says everything outright.The story they end up telling is actually pretty simple, but there are just so many other things that crowd out the much more affecting core of this story: two people still clearly in love with each other, just trying to overcome the hurt that also still exists between them. In bits, in moments, the two kind of make that work. But the movie itself feels so caught up in the norms of their genre to just let the leads take the lead.

HEARTFELT. This film presents a distinct, powerfully affecting kind of love story to prove that the standard CGM formula has still some unique perspectives to spin and explore. Here‚Äôs a mind dump (with little spoilers) rendered in the same fashion as the film‚Äôs break-build narrative, starting off with negatives (baka awayin ako ng fans, lol), wrapping up with positives. 1. The opening voiceovers are certainly moving but seem lengthier than necessary. I hate that I feel like I‚Äôm being spoon-fed.2. Daniel‚Äôs character is rather poorly developed. And the choice to reveal his backstory through another character‚Äôs verbose lines is quite a disappointment. 3. I am totally confused about (what I think is) the turning point where Primo has to leave because that‚Äôs obviously what he is asked to, then is instantly being chased by George afterwards. There is no question about Kathryn‚Äôs acting, but seriously I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúGirl, why are you crying? Pinaalis mo ‚Äòdi ba?‚Äù And when he returns, she says something like ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what I actually meant because I was just tired, and that I wanted you to fight for us that night.‚Äù Ang labo. 4. The prepossessing bike scene gets less delightful when Primo starts throwing gibberish pick-up lines. Ganda na sana eh. Rickety in part but there‚Äôs so much that makes it worthy as a whole:5. Editing does not look as though it‚Äôs rushed. ‚ÄòButi naman. 6. A dialogue-heavy scene backdropped by Amsterdam‚Äôs glaring flower fields and lovely sunset is my favorite. How would you feel if you‚Äôre in a beautiful place, talking to someone you love about how your lives got better after you painfully parted ways? Tearful acceptance, ganun. Ako, hindi ko alam. Unfathomable. 7. Second favorite is the harana/apology scene. Pain and kilig stirred together. 8. It may not be picture-perfect, but it‚Äôs a warehouse of authentic messages, inspirational ideologies, and lessons in love, which I gladly take away:- Relationships take great, great effort to maintain. It‚Äôs easy to give love and be happy when things are going well. But what happens when life suddenly feels as though it‚Äôs caving in with a spirit-crushing weight? Ang tanong eh kung kaya mo pa. Pero kung siya ayaw na, tama na. Ginawa ko na ‚Äòyan. Okay naman ako. Pero ako lang ‚Äòyun. - I give a nod everytime Primo says ‚ÄúSayang iniwan kita, nagkahiwalay tayo,‚Äù and George will answer ‚Äúbut we became better persons.‚Äù Eh kasi tama naman. We don‚Äôt grow when things are easy, comfortable, and effortless. We grow when we face something beyond what we‚Äôre capable of handling. Kahit magkahiwalay pa kayo. Again, ako lang ‚Äòto. - For the most beautiful part: Just because we think our heart is broken doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs incapable to love again. (Sa‚Äôkin talaga galing to? Hahaha!) It‚Äôs those times when we have to step aside, heal in whatever foolish way we can, and remind ourselves of what keeps us going. It‚Äôs when we think na wala nang dahilan magmahal ulit kasi masasaktan ka lang ulit, that instead of curling up and hiding from the world, we gather our scattered bits of resolve to keep moving forward, whether with someone from the past, with someone new, or with yourself alone. Friend, life is worth every single moment. Be open to lessons from your hardships and misfortunes ‚Äî they will build within you an unshakable passion, acceptance, understanding, and LOVE. THOU redefines my idea of living life, makes me want to fall in love again.
Solid first act. Gets droopy in the middle but is held up by Kathryn Bernardo's impeccable acting. Ends on a really sweet, heartfelt note.

I really dislike films where the movie itself tries to force you to root for a deeply problematic relationship, and excuse selfish behavior.Other than Daniel Padilla, the film doesn't work at a fundamental level. It's that bad to me.Edit: i was far too generous the first time

It felt like it's a poem-you've-read-before's movie version. Though there are these cringeworthy Amsterdam scenes and romantic lines that could have been more effective if it was said in vernacular, the formidable leads were still able to hit the soft spot with their relentless charm and chemistry.

This is one of Molina's best films although, that's not really saying much to be honest. It's elevated by the thoughtful and strong performances of its two leads but it's ultimately let down by a script that relies too much on cheesy lines that never really feel necessary and sometimes, some scenes are just a bit longer than they should have been. Overall, it's still really entertaining and Padilla and Bernardo prove once again why they are huge stars.

I'll be honest, I am not a fan of this love team. It's just not for me. To each his own.But I saw this film anyway, mostly for friendship. The intention was good, the plot was interesting and surprisingly not cliche (as is much of the mainstream Filipino films are these days, tbh), soundtrack was also nice. Just not a fan of the cast - and it's not because I'm not a fan of the couple. Even the supporting cast fell short. Tried my best to not be biased about it, but I found myself cringing a few times because of the sucky acting. Side note: Actors act, singers sing. That's how the world should work. Overall, decent film. You'll thoroughly enjoy it more if you're a Kathniel fan, I guess?

George‚Äôs character was somehow all of us in general. Sometimes we get tired or sometimes we feel like almost giving up but in the end we just want somebody to be there for us in that moment. To make us feel or just even tell us that everything will be okay. Primo‚Äôs character is also us in some moments of this so called life that we are in. We pursue our passion and only think of ourselves (I think, this is the majority of the millenials). But sometimes, unfortunately there will come a time that we‚Äôll be in a crossroad and we only have to choose one path. Yourself or not yourself. They say, you are lucky if you found what you are passionate about and make a career out of it. But sometimes our stars doesn‚Äôt align in what we know we want to pursue and what we need or know to do. I consider myself lucky in my career. Not YET financially but I love what I‚Äôm doing and where I am at. My takeaway in the story is that if you love someone, fight for this person. No matter what. Sometimes like Primo, I ask myself, what if I fought for him?

This is a sweet film about two young people who fall in love, fall apart, and come back together. The film has three languages (I think) English, Spanish, and Tagalog (at least I'm guessing so) and cycles through them interspersedly which is fascinating to me because I can't even get beyond the one I currently speak. Both actors look a bit too young to make the time span of the movie completely believable -- they're either together seven years and then separated two or those two years are included in the seven, either way there's supposed to be at least seven years between when they first meet and when the film starts but they don't really look it. Overall a sweet film if nothing surprising.

In this film, when a girl says no, it means ‚Äúyes but try harder‚Äù which sends a wrong message to the audience. Toxic relationships are toxic. Let‚Äôs not justify them. Primo was an asshole and his behavior was unacceptable. I‚Äôm pissed he got redemption. Also, if my asshole father abandoned my family, why the fuck would I want to see him? Let‚Äôs not further perpetuate the notion that being blood related is enough for forgiveness. My favorite rom-com bit is when they were selling their furniture then flashes back to what they were to them. Kathryn never looked this beautiful, proud of her. Hope one day she grows out of Kathniel and figure out better and more independent characters that don‚Äôt rely on cheesy romances.

I have always been checking for Daniel Padilla because I do think he has an impressive talent and very natural acting and charisma. I liked Kathryn in her previous shows and movies when she was younger but while she grew up, some of her acting appeared to be too mannered for me. In this movie however, Director Cathy Garcia-Molina flipped the script and made Kathryn shine more out of the duo. Don't get me wrong, Daniel is still a great screen presence but he was encumbered by what is, in my opinion, a deeply unlikable character while Kathryn got to play a long suffering and determined young lady and really got her chance to shine here. There are lots of parts of this movie that lost my rapt - the out of place Amsterdam part and newcomer Darren Espanto's stilted acting, to name a few. But Kathryn and Daniel's special brand of chemistry still drives this movie home.

Duhhh.. gue speechless.. film yang sempurna menuturkan tema pasang surut sebuah hubungan asmara jangka panjang yang dibina selama 7 tahun. Tentang bagaimana kedua insan berusaha saling memahami, menjaga hati dan ketika keduanya dihadapkan pada satu konflik yang memuncak, mereka saling mengharapkan dan berekspektasi lebih terhadap reaksi pasangannya. Georgina (Bernardo) ingin pasangannya, Primo (Padilla) lebih terlihat berjuang, padahal mereka punya 'pertempuran' dan cara berjuang yang berbeda dari sejak pertama mereka bertemu.Relate banget filmnya.. di saat pasangan harus saling mendukung, dari yang awalnya percaya dengan passion Primo, dan menerima segala kekurangannya dan bersabar. Georgina, merasa lelah sekian lama bekerja sambil kuliah, membayar tagihan, mengurusi rumah warisan neneknya, sementara Primo sibuk mengejar passionnya, yang awalnya membuat Georgina jatuh cinta.Hubungan keduanya sirna, saat Georgina merasa lelah dengan perjuangannya, mengeluh dan marah untuk pertama kalinya dan mengusir Primo. Ia berharap Primo bertahan mendengarkan keluhannya, bersabar menghadapi amarahnya dan lebih berjuang membantu lelahnya. Tetapi Primo malah pergi, membawa kekecewaan, rasa tidak dipercaya dan kegagalan. Keduanya berpisah dan baru bertemu kembali setelah 2 tahun.Primo kembali lagi, berusaha memperbaiki, tapi Georgina menganggapnya sudah terlambat. Semua sudah berakhir, tanpa mereka ketahui rahasia dan 'pertempuran hati' yang Primo pendam 2 tahun yang lalu.Filmnya punya chemistry yang bagus dan mengupas permasalahan dalam hubungan yang dalam dan logis. Rasanya semua orang bisa mengalami konflik dalam film ini. Kedekatan personal dan emosional jadi kunci di film yang punya teknis yang sederhana tapi dengan kekuatan skripnya menjelma jadi film yang kuat menggali emosi lewat dialog2 bagus dan dalam.My fave romance of all time.

‚Ä™Has a very simple premise, but #TheHowsofUs become a very enjoyable romantic comedy. Some of subplot maybe not really works and has a few cliche moments. But, Cathy Garcia-Molina's direction had her sensitivity to make this one become a very cute yet emotional film especially for the ending. The chemistry between Kathryn and Daniel was irrestisible. If you can't help for this kind of film, well bring the tissues then.

Film yang begitu lekat dan hangat. Kadang suka sebel, marah dan senyum-senyum sendiri ketika nonton film ini. Momen-momen ketika kalian pacaran tentunya dengan banyak sekali cobaan yang ada. Dan jangan lupa siapkan tisu kalau mau menonton film ini.

Meski ceritanya sederhana, The Hows of Us tetap membuat saya terkesima dengan kisah antara kedua tokoh utamanya. Chemistry, dialog yang manis, komedi, kisah romantis, serta adegan emosional terasa begitu menarik hati. Wajar saja kalau film ini merupakan film Filipina terlaris sepanjang masa.Cinepolis Kalibata City

Wajar jika The Hows Of Us adalah film Filipina terlaris sepanjang masa. Ia mempercakapkan perjalanan cinta dengan manis juga begitu mengharukan, walau memang‚Äîseperti Rasyid Harry katakan‚Äîterlampau lama. Salah satu drama romantis terbaik 2018.

Forget about the Filipino-romance formula plots, but the execution made me forget how appealing this can be. The lines said can be repeated by other Filipino drama-rom coms (or context are pretty much the same), but I just remembered that the screenwriters are the same people who wrote One More Chance which made me realize why this film gave much emotion. The story is plain simple and it was going okay as it goes along, but I think the father/Amsterdam thing was unnecessary, however, I'm not hating the not-tulips-but-other-flowers-on-the-field scene when they both finally realized they've become better people with their separation.It was also nice to see the evolution of this love team's acting; they just get better and better as time goes by, giving more opportunities for them to go with mature roles ‚Äî including this one. I wouldn't hate it if they didn't end up together and had a good friendship instead, but of course...

I don't know if I have nearly as many questions about how this couple happened than I do about the one in "She's Dating a Gangster". This onscreen romance between Kathryn Benardo and Daniel Padilla can only be healthier than their last one under Cathy Garcia-Molina, but we're still talking about an aspiring musician and a medical student moving in together after she inherits her great aunt's hows-I mean house. I don't know how mature the film itself is with that wordplay in the title, so of course it's not too long before the med student gets tired of supporting the bum. Years later, "he just happens" to return declaring that he is a "changed man", but at least sticks around when he discovers that his ex-girlfriend blew up her medical career to whine about breaking up with her boyfriend. As if that's not unhealthy enough, after they ruined their first relationship with too much pressure, they have to start a new one by selling the house and finding the female lead's estranged father before her brother goes blind from diabetes. Along the way, they figuratively return to the debate club where they literally met to assess the "hows" that will save these lovers, even though the only one that counts is that they're played by Kathryn Benardo and Daniel Padilla. Filipino cinema's hottest power couple are sure to draw a crowd to what bickering they can manage, but the film still has to pander to them to oblivion.The masses might be a bit thrown off by the film's wildly convoluted nonlinear storytelling, and even then, it's mostly hard to keep up with the rapid-fire progression of the characters' arc settling into the house and adapting to their draggier reunion some years later. Something as overdramatic as a flashback structure mostly just shows how contrived this thing is, as a simplistic melodrama that forces conflict in the flashback storyline to spice up an initially "happy" home and facilitate its downfall, and blows the reunion arc on either randomly searching for an estranged father or a grown-ass doctor screaming about the "tragedy" of getting dumped. This film deals with some pretty sophisticated themes on how individuals are complexly shaped by their relationship, and although fairly likable character undergo a lot of change, it's all undone by those "I can't live with you" confrontations and "I can't live without you" declarations. It's never a particularly well-written romp, of course, the comedy being almost singularly embarrassingly juvenile screwball banter with friends or cutesy shenanigans with the couple, whose romantic interplays are devalued by sexual tension and saccharine dramatic progression. For the film to talk about moving into an adult relationship, this is in no way an adult movie, with Cathy Garcia-Molina being just one of many writers on a flimsy committee, and giving up on carrying this above that as directress. As full-hearted as her frantic overstylization, over-scoring, overpacing and overall overhandedness are, it's yet more grating pandering that wears down a superficial romantic dramedy. It's just a fluff piece, and it's sure to please the crowd, sometimes with actually tasteful elements.The wooded suburban house is a key character, and a comely one at that, with a beauty and humility beaming with some of the truest romance in the atmosphere of a film all about the hassle of a couple settling down. This sentimental tone is carried over by Jessie Lasaten's sweetly bright score and Noel Teehankee's dreamily polished cinematography, but without the maturity naturally inherent in that home. Cathy Garcia-Molina's direction just keeps going too far with the romantic disposition, but no matter how cloying this gets, there's always such honesty in such fiery emotion. As melodramatic as the film gets, there are times when Garcia-Molina is simply owning up to that with her dreamy sentiments, trusting that the cheese will be grounded by the admittedly fairly solid character factor. It's a romantic drama about growing up that is in no way grow-up, until there comes a point in both the flashback and present-day segments when the characters really start to break through, losing a grip of their prospects under the pressure of making a home, then reuniting some time later to further contemplate how they function as a unit. Juxtaposing these two processes deepen fairly sharp themes on understanding the differences between healthy dependency and toxic codependency; sacrificing your own prospects and supporting someone else's; and succumbing to the burden of a serious relationship and giving it time to breathe. I can tell you one thing: it's getting hard to see Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla functioning without each other, their radiant chemistry continuing to flourish alongside their bubbly charms and often surprisingly piercing emotional forces, as they try to hold together a film that is having a harder time managing fluff with true maturity.The nonlinear narrative is just part of the incessant contrivances that devalue a would-be mature love story, but not like the grating humor, histrionics and overstylization that render this strict pandering, with enough charm in its craft and punch-up, if not enough depth in its character developments and the leads' chemistry, to save Cathy Garcia-Molina's "The Hows of Us" a likably farcical romantic drama that warms your heart in some places and leave it cold in others.2.5/5 - Adequate

Bingung sebenarnya mau nulis review film ini gimana. Bukan karena filmnya jelek, tapi karena filmnya RELATABLE SEKALI, KAKAK. Aku bingung karena aku pasti kecurcol soal mantan. Aku gatel pengen cerita soal kehidupan percintaanku, sesuatu yang rasanya bisa menjijikkan buat dibaca orang lain. Bisa bikin orang lain memaki, ‚ÄúMANA BAHASAN SOAL FILMNYA, ANJIIIIIIR. MALAH CURHAT SI BANGKEEEEEE.‚Äù But‚Ä¶ fuck it. Aku tulis aja deh. Aku nggak tau mau nulis apa juga. Selain film ini bagus kecuali adegan pas setting-nya berpindah di Amsterdam di mana pas bagian itu terasa membosankan. Bagi yang males dan mual kalau baca curhatan, bisa berhenti sampai di sini.-------------------------BATAS SUCI-----------------------------Tuh, aku bikinin batas sucinya ehehe.Aku ngerasa kenapa nonton ini pas banget dengan momen si mantan ngajak balikan. FYI, aku dan si mantan putus beberapa waktu lalu. Aku diputusin, lebih tepatnya. Ehehe.Film ini seolah bikin aku optimis mau dan bisa balikan sama mantan. Karena filmnya tentang pasangan yang putus terus balikan lagi. Tentang cowoknya yang buat salah terus cowoknya minta maaf, menyadari kalau ternyata dia yang salah dan berusaha berubah. The Hows of Us adalah mimpi basah bagi orang-orang kayak aku. Yang dalam lubuk hatinya pengen balikan tapi takut bakal hancur lagi. Yang ngerasa bingung kalau pake otak, jadinya rasional. Kalau pake hati, bisa senang tapi irasional. Kalau ngikutin otak, wajar banget rasanya kalau nggak balikan. Memang harusnya nggak balikan. Kalau ngikutin hati, rasanya pengen balikaaaaan aja. Memaafkan dengan mudah apa yang telah dilakukan mantan.Aku nggak bilang kalau sepenuhnya mantan yang salah. Aku juga salah. Aku nggak bisa memenuhi ekspektasinya. Aku nggak sesempurna yang dia mau. Aku udah berusaha berubah jadi apa yang dia mau, tapi aku nggak bisa. Rintangan yang dihadapi menuju ke 'arah sana' juga bukan dianggap cobaan, tapi halangan. Aku nggak berhasil meyakinkan dia buat terus berusaha demi aku. Demi kami.Aku paling ingat kata-katanya temannya George (Kathryn Bernardo), salah satu tokoh utama di film ini. ‚ÄúGeorge, I know that story all too well. First, you start to listen. Then you believe what he says. Then you agree what he wants. Then you‚Äôre fooled again, you‚Äôre naive another time! Listen to me, do not repeat the same mistake!‚ÄùGeorge adalah perempuan cerdas yang bisa jadi contoh dari kalimat, ‚ÄúKalau soal cinta, semua orang bisa jadi goblok.‚Äù Temannya George udah kayak Kak Ira, kakak sepupuku, pas nasehatin aku jangan sampai balikan sama mantan.Hiks. Ditambah lagi, George dan Primo (Daniel Padilla), sepasang kekasih yang udah jadi mantan, waktu pacaran punya panggilan sayang. Yaitu Jo.JO ANJEEEEER.KENAPA HARUS JO. ANJEEEEEEEEEEEER.FILM KURANG UAJAAAAAAAR. Ya gimana, aku manggil si mantan waktu masih pacaran dengan nama Jojo. Tapi aku sering panggil dia, ‚ÄúJo,‚Äô dan nama kontaknya di hapeku itu aku tulisin nama Jo. HUAAAAAAA KENAPA BISA KEBETULAN SIIIIH. Film ini brengsek. Patut aku bilang brengsek karena bikin aku optimis aja buat balikan sama si mantan. Bikin mikir kalau aku juga bisa kayak George yang akhirnya balikan sama Primo. Aku nggak bisa bohong dengan bilang aku nggak sayang sama mantan. Aku masih. Nggak berubah. Nggak tau sampai kapan. Aku pengen rasa ini berubah, minimal berkurang sedikit. Tapi malah‚Ä¶. aaaarrrrrrrgh. Cuman kalau balikan lagi, pasti kami berantem lagi. Nyakitin lagi masing-masing.Hahahaha. Hahaha. Haha. Ha.Ih ngeselin ya kalau jadi orang baperan. Mau nonton apapun dibaperin ke diri sendiri.

As a matter of fact, I was cringing for the most parts, the movie also romanticized a problematic relationship. Why???? I enjoyed the first act though, but that was it. The rest? Meh. Totally unwatchable if not for Kathryn. So kudos to her. Dinala niya buong movie, eh. That one star is for Kath and Orange & Lemon‚Äôs music as OST. Also, tangina talaga ng mga lalakeng kuhang-kuha ka sa isang ngiti at kanta nila. Buti na lang masaya na ko.!Anyway, I think I‚Äôm more game to write a 2000-word article on how Friday nights spent watching Pinoy movies with Pinoy friends at Holland Village became a thing.

Sebuah film drama yang mempunyai cerita yang tidak baru.Sebenarnya film ini bisa menjadi tontonan yang menghibur, namun dalam eksekusinya film ini seperti terlalu panjang karena ada cerita sampingan seperti adiknya yang sakit, pencarian sang ayah yang sebenarnya tidak penting. Sehingga menonton film ini cukup melelahkan. Padahal bila film ini fokus terhadap pasang surut hubungan sang tokoh utama, maka film ini sangat manis.Sebuah film dengan rasa opera sabun yang durasinya terlalu lama.Setidaknya lagunya cukup enak didengar.

Membosankan, dari dulu karakter Kathryn dan Daniel begitu2 saja.Ceritanya nggak ada yang spesial sih. Tentang kesuksesan, karier, idealisme, dan cinta. Ada plot adiknya yang mau banget ketemu ayahnya di Belanda. Menurutku itu nggak perlu. Kayak nggak ada efeknya buat jalan cerita utama. Seakan mau pamer aja syut di Amsterdam, setelah sebelumnya di Barcelona di film Barcelona A Love Untold. Tapi bukan berarti buruk. Walau klise, cerita dibuat se-believeable mungkin. Sebab akibatnya. Konsekuensinya. Tentang si perempuan yang muak dengan idealisme cowoknya. Masa si Daniel (eh aku lupa di sini nama peran dia siapa? sudah nonton sebulan lalu) nggak mau nyanyi bahasa Inggris di kafe hanya karena idealisme. Hehehehe. Mending situ nyanyi di kamar mandi, kan beda musisi pro dan musisi kamar. Maksudnya keidealismean dia terlalu banyak dan kurang menohok aja. Bahkan sampai ditinggalkan temen ngebandnya. Mungkin mereka disuruh ganti genre dangdut kali ya sama produser rekamannya sampai Daniel nolak ambil proyek rekaman.Si Kathryn gagal jadi dokter, karena mengurus suami kumpul kebonya. Mereka belum kawin sih. Tapi bebas, kan Filipina. Di sini juga ada wkwkw. Aku suka aja kegerahan Kathryn dengan toxic relationships antara mereka berdua. Kalau cinta itu butuh duit, bukan cuma kepercayaan. Sayang aja mesti happy ending dan mereka balikan lagi. Kalau gue mah ogah, emansipasi ciiinn. Women empowerment üíÅüí™ Sebenarnya kalau kita sering nonton film dan sinetron mereka berdua, mirip lah kayak couple Michelle Zuidith dan Rizky Nassar atau Dimas Anggara. Sutradaranya juga sama aja. Kayak ditulis khusus penggemar mereka. Waktu film ini tayang di bioskop Indonesia, banyak komen filmnya syedih bingitttt. Four Sisters and the Wedding: take my tissue!

I'll be honest, this movies was on my bucketlist so my expectations were kinda high. It's a VERY TYPICAL Filipino romantic film. There was nothing new about it that would make your mind blown. Most of the scenes are those that you can see in other filipino films such as after the break up, the guy will return to win back the lost love of the girl, the "traveling to other places to strengthen the relatonship" and the overly dramatic confrontation scenes. (which in fact 'caused me to be teary eyed lol!) What makes it more exciting was Daniel Padilla and Kathryn Bernardo was in it! They were so good together and you can just feel the love they have for each other. They demonstrated good acting skills and their script- DAMN. Most of it were heartbreaking. Overall, I did like this movie and I can feel that most of the people in the cinema enjoyed it as well.

The first act, sweetie, you're doing amazing! The Amsterdam sequence‚Äîyou don't even go here üò≠üò≠üò≠Just when I thought this film strayed away from formulaic, comfortable rom-com that never fails to have: a hugot festival, kids with parental issues, and the need to go to special places to release repressed feelings, instead it stayed loyal to it. The beginning was so promising, may pa-slow motion pa, but it wasn't consistent. Also, I'm curious as to how and why they make the audio in these types of films. There's something about how voices are amplified too much or smoothened out. Sometimes, it looks like it was dubbed which I find disturbing. Anyway, Kathryn Bernado's acting is stale as ever and I almost pity Daniel Padilla who caged in roles as a charismatic loverboy that it scares me to see him outside it.

While the start and main problem were promising, the formulaic resolution was very disappointing. I just don't get the point of already starting with the post-breakup, and then showing the redeeming value of Primo was with him all along, even before the breakup, as if pointing out that it was all a misunderstanding. This subtly puts the blame on George for not knowing that Primo was actually a good man (she should have just trusted him!).This should have been a film about HOW Primo acknowledges his accountability and redeems himself, and HOW George finally finds in herself the courage to forgive and love again. That would have been less formulaic, less harmful, and most probably very endearing.Also, what's with the exaggerated acting? Almost all of them are good to great actors (except of course for Espanto), and yet most of them were also over the top. I think, because they have proven in their other projects that they can act, that it's a directorial problem. Which is also suprising, given that this is Garcia-Molina we are talking about.

the only thing i don't like about this movie is that we all know that their relationship is already toxic and yet we are being forced to root for that said couple. but i also believe that there is a room for change and development for one's self, and both george & primo showed that they did become better people.anyway 1 star because this movie almost made me cry. 2 stars for kathryn bernardo herself, she must be very tired of carrying the whole movie by herself.

This is the first Kathniel project i ever truly liked ‚Äî loved even! In typical Star Cinema fashion, the movie starts with a chaotic scene depicting hyperactive leads that, somehow, lose that hyperactivity through the rest of the film.In another typical Star Cinema fashion, insert the need to shoot in a foreign country. I have to be honest, though ‚Äî those Amsterdam scenes could have also panned out effectively if shot in some remote province in the Philippines. But, yeah, I know Amsterdam doesn‚Äôt require permits for filming there, so I guess Star Cinema took the opportunity to film and have a European vacation at the same time. Typical Filipino showbusiness tactic. Splitting the house in two - seen that many times, mostly in comedies. It did the job for this movie, though. It worked as a story device that did not feel forced.Anyway, Kathryn and Daniel have both really matured in this movie. Especially Kathryn ‚Äî in all her previous movies where she was supposed to play an adult, she didn‚Äôt quite do so well. I mean, acting-wise, she did. But in terms of looks, she always looked like some teenager and, sometimes, even a child. So I commend the styling team for doing a good job with her look for ‚ÄúThe How‚Äôs of Us‚Äù. Her screen presence matured. As for Daniel, boy, has he grown into a man. I especially love him in this role. I love it when men are depicted as soft, vulnerable, and pitiful ‚Äî in the context of a love story, of course.And this ‚Äî I cried. Yup. I tried to hold back the tears, but I just couldn‚Äôt. This is the true hallmark of good storytelling ‚Äî when you fight your emotion, but it gets the better of you.

don‚Äôt get me wrong, kathryn and daniel did well on this film, especially the former who seemingly carried the film on her back (as most critics seem to be saying‚Äî and i agree) but, as there always is an apprehensive but, the storyline was, objectively and personally, not to my taste. not only did it remind me and my mother (who cried very hard might i add) of my parents‚Äô abusive relationship, it was just . . . hard to force myself to like primo. i saw too much of my father in him, a man i hate and have no pity for. they were too alike‚Äî in their actions, words, beings, so how could i forgive one and crucify the other?i think this brings us back to how good of an actor daniel was in this film. i don‚Äôt think it was his best performance, but it definitely wasn‚Äôt his worst. he portrayed primo very well, showcasing the complexities of his being making one question whether or not he really deserves to be forgiven. (i personally would not have forgiven him, i have to say. the relationship that primo and george had was too toxic, and it hit a little too close to home than my liking)there are many things i would still like to say about this film, perhaps i‚Äôll expound more on this when the morning comes. just know that this was a good watch, not the best, not the worst, but good.

"George, I'm sorry.""And what makes that sorry different from all your other sorrys before?"I've always been a devoted admirer of Kathniel, eagerly anticipating each of their upcoming movies. They stand out as my preferred Filipino loveteam, especially since I used to follow Social Seryes on Twitter inspired by their story. My admiration for Daniel Padilla and Kathryn Bernardo deepened after watching this particular film in theaters.While the movie's plot follows the typical, clich√©, and foreseeable pattern of Filipino romance films, I found it delightful because of the remarkable chemistry between the two leads. Somehow, they infused it with a special and heartfelt quality. Kathryn Bernardo's acting deserves special recognition; her exceptional performance left a lasting impact, even stirring my emotions at 3:00 AM.Forgiveness, a challenging virtue, becomes particularly daunting when faced with someone who has caused you pain and shattered your self-esteem. The decision to forgive or harbor perpetual resentment carries immense pressure, complicated further by the fear of disappointing those opposed to your chosen path.I won't deny that Primo was quite the jerk in the past, blinded by his dreams to the harsh realities around him. Despite acknowledging George's struggles in a letter, he failed to take meaningful action. His reckless behavior, fueled by alcohol, exacerbated their financial woes. Fortunately, George displayed remarkable understanding and selflessness. It's heartening that Primo eventually transformed into a better person, learning from his mistakes and genuinely committed to fixing everything.In contrast, I resonate more with George's approach. I refuse to let the same person inflict harm on me once again.

I still think that SDTG is Kathniel's best film (despite the unnecessary medical-related sub-plot), but THOS is so special. This is Daniel Padilla's best. I saw him grow as an actor from the same bad boy teenager roles since Growing Up, and his comfortability on screen makes him better.What I do not like about the film is the same medical-related subplot, the parental issues, friends/family conflicts. Same Cathy Garcia-Molina formula. Same Filipino romcom formula. What made this film better though is how warm and pleasant Kathryn and Daniel act together. Their chemistry made this film work. I would have loved this more if the film focuses on Primo and George's story. More scenes during their stay on Tita Lola's house, what happened after Primo left, and after Primo came back. It's like the Barcelona: A Love Untold. Too many sub-stories that could have been deleted.Overall, I love it. THIS IS DANIEL PADILLA'S MOVIE.

At two hours long, "The Hows of Us" was limited severely by so much bloat and so many tropes that it really made us wonder why they just didn't tell a straightforward story in the first place. But don't get us wrong though, it wasn't a bad experience at all and we actually found ourselves liking this film much more than we anticipated. But its barely middling middle section should have been reworked maybe even removed.For years, Jo (Kathryn Bernardo) and Primo (Daniel Padilla) had a long-lasting relationship so much so that when Jo‚Äôs Aunt died, she left her house to the both of them. But with Primo, a budding musician, failing to attain the success that he feels he is beholden to and with Jo feeling that Primo‚Äôs failures are holding her back, Primo abandons Jo all by herself. A few years pass by when Primo suddenly shows up and wants to fix the wrongs he has done in the past - including his relationship with Jo. But this isn‚Äôt as simple as it sounds as Jo plans to sell their house soon and hasn‚Äôt really forgiven and forgotten that Primo left her to fend for herself. We must admit that ‚ÄúThe Hows of Us‚Äù left us with a heavy dose of mixed feelings. On one hand, its narrative and story really had potential to be substantially and emotionally moving. But the film also suffers because it felt it needed to do genre tropes within its story that was just unnecessary. For example, there‚Äôs a parent or sibling who suffers a sickness in the most opportune time or simply travelling to a foreign country. We wished it just told a more straightforward and down-to-earth story - one that we could actually imagine happening in real-life and not one obviously written for the big screen. While the overall narrative was bloated, the film actually had bright spots. In fact, the first thirty minutes and last thirty minutes were outstanding in our opinion. It had us gripping our seats with emotionally moving moments. Of course, these scenes were bolstered by the great chemistry and acting between Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla. Overall though, ‚ÄúThe Hows of Us‚Äù will make you swoon in key moments and if that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre after, you‚Äôll actually find it a story worth experiencing. Source: www.reeladvice.net/2020/10/the-hows-of-us-movie-review.html

If you saw me crying during this movie, no you didn't. Kathryn Bernardo was amazing in this film. Her acting really matured so much, and you could tell that she and Daniel worked extremely hard on it. The two had revealed that some of their lines had been taken from their own relationship, and it makes a lot of sense. The emotion they'd all put out was genuine, and it was all a lot of great acting. It was also a really good story for the duo's usual repertoire, and I love that they decided to give them a more mature story that was on the level of Cathy Garcia-Molina's masterpieces like One More Chance. It was relatable, fun and heartbreaking all at the same time. It's a great Filipino movie. I highly recommend.

this is peak Pinoy romcom cinema. it has everything you‚Äôd expect; flashbacks and flashforwards, a junket trip to Europe, 2 charismatic leads, etc. what separates this from the fluff is its execution, the story (up until the end) is well crafted and avoids the natural pitfalls of the premise it set up for itself. the protagonists have agency and do not make any decision just for plot contrivance. not to say this is a perfect movie, it has its problems‚Äî the editing and pacing is not quite there. it spends way too much time meandering through Amsterdam, and crafting a Pixar Up-like sequence in the beginning was not necessary if they were only going to spend a lot of running time going through the past all over again, so there is no economy of storytelling present. my biggest problem though is the ending. i understand why they did it the way they did, but imo it was completely unnecessary and actually harms the characters‚Äô growth during the movie. SPOILER what the ending does is retcon the movie‚Äôs story; we find out in the end that Primo actually knew he was being a selfish prick before he left, but instead of actually doing something about it, he instead, what, wrote a letter? that makes it okay? that actually makes it worse, because now we know he had a CHOICE to be better 2 years ago, but he chose not to. his 2 years of change therefore did not matter because it implies he in fact didn‚Äôt change, at all. then they have George APOLOGIZING to him? as if anything was her fault? that is wrong on so many levels. this development looks unfortunately to have been put there only to create a reason for George to get back together with Primo in time for the movie to end, but this was completely unnecessary. Primo has grown as a person, he‚Äôs already shown this to George, and George already acknowledges that he has. there was no need for the letter. instead, what they should have done was, after all the items have been sold off, have both of them say farewell to their past selves, the people that owned that house, and reintroduce each other as new people. have the movie end with George agreeing to go on a first date with Primo, a chance that this time around, things will work out.

A friend asked me to watch it and I thought I'd give it a try. My eyes couldn't handle the amount of eye rolls I did in the time I wasted watching this movie. Reasons for my eye-roll:1. Direk Cathy Garcia's signature ill-fitted wigs. Seriously, why?2. Overly cheesy dialogue. Nobody talks like that in real life, especially those 2 leads, it just doesn't suit them. It's so forced.3. Meh plotline. Nothing new there. It's obviously a money-grabbing, fan service blandness.4. Not well-acted at all. Not one of them. But especially, Kathryn. Please, crying easy doesn't mean your acting is effective.5. Philippine cinema formula. Yes, let's shoot at overseas location to use the beautiful sceneries as background and our studio gave us extra budget anyway eventhough it doesn't really add anything to the story itself. Check.6. The unnecessarily long runtime of 117 minutes. There's lot of useless stuff there. Does this film think it's an epic?7. What's up with that end credits scene? Soooo cringey.8. If Kathniel and Direk Cathy think this is their mature take on romance movie, they're deluded. It's another pinoy love team movie crap wrapped in shiny paper designed to tickle non-thinking fans so the movie team can reap the blockbuster benefits.

Ugh boy. It started with a promising first act that got me really hooked on to the movie and liking it right away. There were scenes that were all too real and relatable. Then the second act came and this movie just falls into like any other Filipino romantic drama films with the ‚Äúreturn of the exes and still hung up from each other after not seeing or communicating after many years but it felt like nothing has changed and we still love each other so much that we end up together because LOVE CONQUERS ALL ADVERSITIES‚Äù trope with a little bit of an identity crisis from our supporting characters as a side plot.I really thought this film was gonna give us a tale of couples dealing with ups and downs and eventually, a breakup and going through the transition of being single after being in a committed relationship for so long. It did touch that issue in the first act but it was so rushed and I just didn‚Äôt feel any sympathy or connection with the characters. I really believe this movie isn‚Äôt really worth the hype.Phenomenal acting from Kathryn but still unimpressed with Daniel‚Äôs acting ability still. The Hows of Us is a drama romcom type film about a Filipino boyfriend musician and a girlfriend on her way to being a doctor growing individually as well as through their relationship in ties with their new home purchase. The film touches on aspects of romance/love, aspects of grief loss, aspects of depression, aspects of addiction, aspects of being a homeowner, aspects of negative pride, aspects of romantic relationships/friendships, aspects of maturity, aspects of family, and aspects of diabetic retinopathy amongst other points. The camera work is on point. The acting partners fulfill the film. I find the film funnier than sad. The film has some interesting messages about relationships. Though I think a lot is simply put together to fluff the film/make it make more sense toward the end, I find the film entertaining.

hindi ko alam if i‚Äôm just getting back into pinoy movies or my star cinema melodrama bias is acting up but i really liked this movie. kathryn is such a good actor and i‚Äôm realizing that more than ever. daniel is decent at most but it does feel natural to see him with kathryn‚Äî and that plays a huge part on how we see him on screen. most actors are great aside from darren. palagi naman may ini-introduce na ‚Äúyoung talent‚Äù ang star cinema in all of their movies na hindi talaga marunong umarte so i guess masasanay ka na din. yun lang, ang pangit at awkward talaga. isa pang pansin ko: color grading sa amsterdam scenes sobrang processed! you‚Äôre already in amsterdam, might as well follow its natural vibe instead of presenting it as a much brighter, summery place compared to the philippines (where it‚Äôs always bright and summery). plot-wise, decent pero overused as usual. sa script lang lagi nagkakatalo ang mga star cinema melodramatic romance blockbusters and this was average. kathryn lang talaga nagdala. and she did a damn good job! parang character niya sa movie, dalang-dala niya si daniel. good for her! go girl! ayun, overall ay bigyan natin siya ng 3.5 stars. it‚Äôs definitely good enough to be called generally well-made. at napaiyak niya ako so laking factor din yun for this very serious and very lengthy review in the very revered letterbox.

The Hows Of Us could've been a strong film, especially with Kathryn Bernardo's effective acting. But the topsy turvy storytelling ruined a good experience. It started off too serious and heavy, then shifted to a corny rom-com approach and a third act that's unnecessary (ma-justify lang ng prod team pag-abroad nila under Star Cinema's expense). Daniel Padilla's acting is generic and was overshadowed by Kathryn's more upfront character. Still, they do kilig scenes the best. The dialogue would hit couples who experienced a similar dilemma as Primo and George - and that's a real dart to the heart.
"'Yan naman kasing tita-lola niyo e, masyadong naniwala na forever ang loveteam niyo e."
Nakakaasar ang sakit pero ang ganda.

The film's premise surely captures the kind of sentimentality that is born out of selfless devotion. George (Kathryn Bernardo) represents every doting lover who understands that love is both a struggle and sacrifice. But she's human enough to reach her breaking point, that non-singular moment Primo (Daniel Padilla), her lover, erodes into a miserable man. That's outright promising, given an opportunity to go deep into the characters' core. Until the narrative submits to Star Cinema formula. While Primo tries to win George back, a lot of other things happen, all brazenly pointing to them realizing they need to be back together, even if he decides to set her free--a banal device that aims to make love look elusive but more intense. Because how are these two characters supposed to respond to other charcters whose sole duty is to remind them that they still love each other? The sequences in Amsterdam feel like you're watching a different film, with characters so eager to accomplish something for a great cause. The attempt at proving its significance by way of editorializing the flowers and the sunset does not put weight on either the characters or the narrative itself. Daniel effortlessly delivers, his eyes expressing the right emotions. Kathryn tries hard, a few times she's hitting it. Other times she's like a dainty, vulnerable young girl being forced to battle tough times. Her eyes convey ambiguity rather than perceptive and penetrating responses that don't demand words. Her delivery of "quotable quotes" and the lines in the debate scene sounds like a graded recitation (yung mukhang minemorize nang maigi).And then the film gets too didactic, telling us what we should make of how Primo and George triumphed at their story and how we should distinguish battle and war as metaphors for love (kung maka-figure of speech!). The film is supposed to tackle maturity in relationship, but it appears that its depiction does not quite go with its marketing. And Star Cinema is not bothered by such incongruency. It just continues to shape love through a narrative that always turns factitious and simplistic. It does not mind reducing it into the fundamentals of melodrama and simplified association or discourse.

The second highest grossing movie of the Philippines of all time is indeed a gem. The Hows of Us is in fact an anti-love story. The movie explores not the best moments in a relationship but sets it‚Äôs focus on the moments that were the beginning of the end. The calm vibe and the direct confrontations of the couple make the movie captivating and leave a bitter taste. Bernardo and Padilla act so damn good in this film that I had to check if they indeed broke up in real life. So many emotional moments and the question ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs right?‚Äù pull the viewer into the story. The rain scene is one of the most legendary moments in Filipino cinema for me. So many emotions with so less words really got me. I really loved the movie and can understand why every Filipino I met recommended me this masterpiece. It‚Äôs worth watching!

Perhaps the most formally assured of these--Garcia-Molina plays with temporality in interesting ways, and utilizes spaces extremely well, using set design to suggest barriers between her leads--and these are my favorite KathNiel performances so far, but, I found the story a bit too busy, cramming extra sub-plots (a health scare AND a long-lost father?) that distract from the central relationship (and they do much more than merely distract: they actively conspire against it, as it keeps alive the dream that external events could solve the problems in their relationships....which is never the case, the changes must come from within!)But perhaps I'm being harsh, as this is a serious, adult drama (albeit with moments of levity), one that isn't content with the rosy-eyed "relationships are easy" view (nor one that ignores its characters material circumstances; money pressures drive all the key events in the film).

Mikko : "George, katakan yang sebenarnya. Untuk apa garis ini?"George : "Untuk Primo. Untuk mengingatkannya bahwa dia memiliki batasan.Mikko : "Hmm, ini bukan untuk menghentikan Primo yang datang kedalam hidupmu lagi. Ini untuk menghentikanmu agar tidak jatuh cinta lagi padanya."Awee : "Karna ketidakhadiran membuat hati semakin dekat, tetapi kehadiran menempatkan hati dalam bahaya.The Hows of Us (2018) bercerita tentang sepasang kekasih yang pernah saling mencintai, kemudian putus dan bersatu kembali. Terdengar simpel, sederhana dan sudah ketebak. Tapi yang membuat film ini berbeda dengan drama percintaan pada umumnya adalah pengemasannya. Pemilihan kata dalam dialognya yang sempurna, banyak yang relate dengan kisah seperti ini dan film ini juga sangat jujur dan realistis. Cathy Garcia-Molina berhasil mengangkat kisah biasa yang sering dialami dalam hubungan, sesuai realita, namun dikemas dengan sangat baik. Film kedua dari sutradara perempuan Filipina Cathy Garcia-Molina yang aku tonton. Berawal dari Hello, Love, Goodbye (2019) dengan soundtracknya "Ikaw At Ako" yang masih terngiang-ngiang dikepala menuntunku ke film ini, dan aku ketagihan dengan caranya bertutur dalam filmnya, jujur aku menikmatinya. The Hows of Us (2018) juga kabarnya memecahkan banyak rekor perfilman di Filipina dan menjadi film terlaris sepanjang masa di Filipina.Duet Kathryn Bernardo dan Daniel Padilla udah kayak benar-benar pasangan pada umumya, natural kali gak lebay dan berlebihan. Oh ya baru tau juga aku kalo mereka katanya dinobatkan sebagai pasangan klop yang sering dipasangkan diberbagai serial drama dan film. Kalo di Indo mungkin kayak Rizky Nazar sama Michelle Ziudhit kali ya, yang selalu jadi pasangan di FTV, film, atau series. Makanya chemistri mereka berdua udah matang kali.

Streaming on Netflix now is this topgrossing 2018 Filipino drama that i somehow liked and shamefully but not secretly enjoyed and bawled my eyes out to. üòÉüòÉ It tells the story of former lovers Primo and George who, at the beginning of the film, relive the days and sad occasions that led to their break-up. For fans of Filipino tearjerkers, a box of tissue may not be enough for this film. It will squeeze you out dry but you will not be complaining. This movie hits all the right formula in the genre. From the beautiful cast to the relatable relationship drama that‚Äôs been a staple of Philippine cinema for decades now. The story is somewhat typical but the storytelling is fresh. The conflict is as old as Sharon Cuneta‚Äôs first movie (or could be older) but the execution somehow feels novel. There are many cutesy scenes definitely constructed for the diehard fans of the loveteam but it somehow does not offend or get in the way of the developing drama. There is a subplot that will not ordinarily work but somehow works here. Every emotion this movie elicits from the audience is definitely earned. The great character actress Odette Khan appears in a cameo towards the end of the movie that only made me love this film more.‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

My second rewatch thoughts:This film is actually kind of good. What I don't like about it is how unrealistic some of the scenes are, but it's saved by the amazing performance of Kathryn and her co-star Daniel. The chemistry they both have is seen clearly in here. Of course, it wouldn't be a Star Cinema film without the following:1. an emotional scene while raining2. going abroad3. medical issues4. daddy/mommy issues5. cheesy and sometimes even cringy lines that feels unrealistic if said in real life.With all of these in mind, I enjoyed the film because it shows the struggle between the people, and how we should always have each other's back no matter what. " The story they end up telling is actually pretty simple, but there are just so many other things that crowd out the much more affecting core of this story: two people still clearly in love with each other, just trying to overcome the hurt that also still exists between them. "

Akala ko nung una heavy drama to..... 1. Ang ganda sa umpisa kaso naiba yung direksyon ng kwento nung kalagitnaan hanggang huli2. Contrary sa nakita kong reactions ng fans, di ako agree na problematic si Primo. Oo, idealistic siya at ma-pride. Pero bata pa siya nun. Atsaka tingin ko may pagkukulang din si George. Sa relasyon kasi, dapat may communication. Bigayan kumbaga. Kaso, pareho silang nagsasarili ng hinanakit nila. Pwede naman maayos yan sa masinsinang usapan. Di sinabi ni George yung expectations niya kay Primo at nagtiis nalang siya sa gilid hanggang napuno na siya3. Gusto ko pang makilala si Primo. Parang dito sa movie na to, albeit lovestory siya, mas focused kay George yung kwento. Naging 'pixie dream girl' si Primo. Gusto ko siya. Partly siguro dahil ang charismatic ni Daniel Padilla üòÇ4. May ibang plot lines and characters na unnecessary at naging plot device lang sila. Gaya nung past romance movie na napanood ko, di na kelangan pumunta sa ibang bansa para gawing nakakakilig yung story. Tbh, parang irrelevant nga sa main story yung Amsterdam plot nila.5. Sobrang rare talaga siguro ng filipino romance (lalo na yung focused sa loveteam) na maging grounded sa reality. May ibang lines sa movie na kung di korni eh unrealistic. Like, wala namang taong nakakaisip agad ng hugot line and take note, yung sobrang madrama pa. Gusto ko lang siguro talaga ng romance story na makatotohanan. Yung pakiramdam mo totoong tao talaga yung mga characters at hindi para for kilig lang

I‚Äôve watched this film countless times and I just want to watch it again because of the soundtrack number one, the story and because I‚Äôm sick and in no mood to watch new movies. Plus I missed this movie because of the trend that‚Äôs going around tiktok right now tumawid ka na baby. It reminds me of him in a bittersweet way. Primo the ultimate red flag. I‚Äôm quite happy na alam ko sa sarili ko that I would never let this happen to me under any circumstance. It‚Äôs just not possible for me be in this situation. First I have a rule I made for myself, that if I want to be in a relationship or to experience relationships it would be during high school. Because I won‚Äôt be going to college with a boyfriend. I can‚Äôt afford distraction, medicine is already too much I can‚Äôt afford to bother with another humans physical and mental health? Plus what do you need a man for? What exactly is their use? You won‚Äôt gain anything from, physical touch is 0% on my love language so men would be a 100% hindrance in my case. And don‚Äôt start with ‚Äúmakakahanap ka din ng katapat mo‚Äù or ‚Äúbitter, sino nanakit sa ‚Äòyo?‚Äù Wala. Tumahimik ka nalang because like men I don‚Äôt need an opinion from you about myself. If I‚Äôm gonna be honest, I like Primo sa una, he is totally my type, passionate and knows what he wants in life. He‚Äôs also smart, musikero plus he‚Äôs Daniel Padilla for goodness sake? But my favorite character in this movie would still be Mikko my love the only one who has sense. But kahit ilang beses kong panuorin ‚Äòrong movie na ‚Äòto ‚Äòpag hindi ako maga pause babaha nanaman here sa bahay. I tend to invalidate peoples feelings ‚Äòpag nasabi nila na about sa relationship kung bakit sila depressed. And for all the people feelings whom I invalidate you deserve an apology. I‚Äôm so so sorry. My mindset used to be makipag break ka na tapos na lahat ng problema mo I mean for me hindi parin s‚Äôya mahirap but maybe for others it won‚Äôt be that easy and I‚Äôm slowly opening to that possibility. I‚Äôm glad God didn‚Äôt give me a friend like George because I only would cry with her because of how much I care about her and I would go to jail because I would accidentally kill Primo. I love Kathryn and Daniel‚Äôs acting, I love all their movies omit Barcelona from the list I didn‚Äôt appreciate that movie quite as much. I love Can‚Äôt help falling in love, she‚Äôs dating the gangster of course a classic and this film. This movie has the potential to have my 5 stars and like if it weren‚Äôt for Darren Espanto can someone please remove him from the movie. I literally skip every time I see him, his acting was not it. He acts too young for his age in the movie, ‚Äòyung eye sight may problema sa‚Äôyo not mentally. I‚Äôm so sorry for saying all this but seriously, ang childish? Who made him an actor? He‚Äôs a singer not an actor, porket na famous doesn‚Äôt mean he has the talent to act, y‚Äôall could literally choose anyone tapos he doesn‚Äôt look remotely close to the younger version of Yohan, that little kid did it better by the way. He infuriated me more than Primo did all through the movie.Na delete ‚Äòyung other review ko fml. Anyway I just finished the movie and earlier I said I‚Äôm so glad that it is impossible for me to experience something like this, but at the end the pain and love of the kiss George and Primo shared made me think what it feels like to fall in love and fall out of love and fall in love all together. I don‚Äôt think they ever stopped loving each other but you get my point. I could never experience loving or being loved that hard ever. Anyway, where is the new kathniel film?! Honest thought, this could've been a good (not great) movie if George and Primo didn't end up together. The first few minutes of the film was okay, a bit realistic, but onwards, it became super cheesy and frustrating. Please, for the love of God, free Kathryn Bernardo from Daniel Padilla and Cathy Garcia Molina (and other mainstream directors). She either greatly overshadows DJ's acting skills or DJ drags her down with his acting (or the lack thereof). She also wouldn't grow as an actress if she just keeps getting the same role with different names. Cathy Molina has done it again with her favorite movie formula: the toxic guy gets in a relationship with the positive strong woman, they break up, guy or girl goes to a different country and then goes back to the Philippines years later, guy woos girl (redemption arc), girl forgives guy, and they live happily ever after. God, this is why Filipinos love to romanticize problematic relationships and toxic men.

‚ÄúPatience.‚ÄùThis is the moral of the movie. George and Primo showed a realistic relationship. It is not always a romantic one, sometimes it can be sad and heartbreaking. They let each other because they are tired ‚Äî but letting go each other makes them grow and be the person they want to be. It is a matter of staying through thick and thin, through your darkest days. It is all about the patience we have in love. Sometimes we get tired, but it doesn't mean we don't want anymore. We just get tired, but we can rest.Maybe one of the lines that I can forget is, ‚Äúwe cannot survive to a battle if we fight each other, but staying together can conquer the battle.‚ÄùThis is one of the best Filipino movie I've ever watch, and undeniably the best KathNiel film ever produced. No doubt, this movie is the 2nd Highgest Grossing Filipino of all time. A masterpiece.

I liked this more than I expected. My expectations were so much lower than what I got.I just wished they deviated away from romcom because they definitely tried that out a bit for the first act, and for me it feels too forced.When the serious tone went on for the second act until it ended, that mood and pace worked for me better. I feel like they should've just stuck to that. But I get the romcom execution of the first act since they want to engage audience better.Good one to watch if you want a introspection about the sours of life and love. Not a fun one though so expect emotions.

Love the cold open--contemporary and innovative.Primo's a fucking red flag, egocentrically manipulative as ever. But perhaps Tita Lola was the real antagonist here, charot.Galing ng EO product placement.Very clich√©, nakaka-cringe, as always with KathNiel films, but it‚Äôs their best films I've watched.I was wondering bakit kailangan umuulan pag may strong heartfelt scene between the two of them. I figured it must be symbolism for George's turmoiled feelings toward Primo. Tulips are definitely a symbolism as well for George's ideal partner. Primo gave him a plastic ones when he was courting her.Background music or the musical scoring can be a little excessive in some scenes, but I realized that commercial local films do be like that. Was it necessary to resolve George and her brother's daddy issue? I don't think that was essential, but the film could've been done without the Amsterdam trip. It could've ended with when they already sold the house. The whole Amsterdam trip and there on was like a second act.Overall, despite being cliche, good execution. Deserve naman ang pagiging batikan ni Direk Cathy Garcia-Molina, time-tested na rin. Subok na ng panahon, ganern.George's mistake was falling in love with Primo's potential.Personally, I resonate with George with her territorial and sungit trait; but damn, she's right, she's dumb and weak when it comes to the fucking guy. I WOULDN'T tolerate Primo's comeback if I were her. Pero feel ko binalikan niya lang din out of convenience and because first and only love. Fave character ko si Mikko dito, the very logical friend.Disappointing ending for me, rupok.

The two stars are solely for Kathryn's PAGOD NA PAGOD NA PAGOD NA PAGOD NA AKO coz daaaamn the delivery is so good I felt thatRemove that scene and I will immediately give this a 0/5 for romanticizing problematic relationships. Primo is everything I don't want in a partner. George has very low self-esteem and lacks self-respect. Sacrificing your future and missing your NMAT exam for a prideful but useless man??? PURE IDIOCY. I can't even side nor feel pity for George. I'm so sorry sweet but you brought this upon yourself. I want to hit her in the head at least just once to wake her up from her own stupidity. I didn't even finish this movie. I stopped watching around the 30-minute mark when I was hinted that they'll surely get back together again. I just hate the "going blind for love" trope so much. This is a good portrayal of stupid immature young love, though, I'll give them that. Other than that, the story has no redeeming qualities unless it's rewritten so that Primo and George don't get back together again.

Realistic, emotional, and heartwarming. I really admire Primo‚Äôs character development to fight for his love for George. He was tireless in spite of the actuality that George repeatedly rejected his return in her life, that‚Äôs where I deeply feel that Primo‚Äôs true love for George kept going and it also kept on growing profusely as the time passed by. In the middle of the story, I was kind of confused by Primo‚Äôs behavior which was still blurry about where will they take their future to? I daresay it‚Äôs very related to the lives in the present time, especially for couples who want to bring their relationships to an improved or more serious level. I feel like watching real life experiences of a couple who became wise with their life experiences, hence it feels so real. It truly deserves a great rating!

unmasking the romanticized toxic relationship in this film A movie that challenges to explore the sinister aspects of romance exists in an era where love stories predominantly captivate us as individuals. The movie "The Hows Of Us" defies preconceived assumptions of what romance is and instead leads us on an introspective excursion through the perilous waters of toxic relationships. This movie analysis challenges our preconceived ideas and compels us to face the unsettling reality that love can at times be‚Ä¶

I think we can see parts of ourselves on both George and Primo. May mga panahon na we are ready to give everything up for our partners, even our individual dreams, hoping that everything will work out in the end. After all, sino bang hindi gusto yung taong mahal nila hanggang sa dulo, sa dulo kung saan masaya na kayo?Minsan din tayong naging Primo; desperately chasing our passions in life kahit hindi pa praktikal. Well, art should be a liveable job naman technically, but we all know the reality rn. Still, we all had a little bit of Primo in ourselves believing na what if our passion can be our career at the same time. But mahirap din maging George at Primo. While Primo was chasing his dreams, he forgot that he has a partner to take care of and consider. Si George naman, kakaasikaso at asiste kay Primo, nakalimutan na yung mga sarili niyang pangarap. For me, this is what made the movie realistic.What I didn't like though was the fact na nagkabalikan sila and how they approached it. Para kasing nabura rin kung gaano ka-shitty yung ginawa ni Primo kay George over the course of their relationship. For me, dapat hindi sila nagbalikan talaga. Hence 4 stars. Kasi nga I rate for the vibes.

+ There is a hint of a better-written film in "The Hows of Us". The supposed premise of lovers continuing their emotionally halted journey in life together starts of strong. But with the number of expositions squattered throughout this film, mediocre characterizations, and underbaked romance, this film fails in deliverying a more memorable love-story. Its themes of redemption, growth, and forgiveness seems to be lop-sided in parts, and Kathryn Bernardo's George was poorly written‚Äîthough Kathryn gave an ecstatic performance. Daniel Padilla as Primo, on the other hand, also gave enough nuance to make his character charming, and surprisingly earnest. Though much is to be desired in how this movie had told us its story, still, there is enough charm in here to win you over, even if it doesn't give you a lasting impression.

revisiting this movie, whether it‚Äôs watching the whole thing or just watching clips of it, always makes me cry very very ugly tears especially the scene where george finally gets to read the letter primo wrote for her 2 years later üòûüòû this movie just portrays the heartbreak of meeting the right person at the right time yet circumstances and bad choices getting in the way so beautifully, it just hits you right to the corei‚Äôve never personally experienced anything george and primo have, at least not to that degree, but they made me feel like i carried george‚Äôs burden and felt the guilt primo felt the entire time üôÅüôÅ these characters are just work of fiction yet they feel SO real, i honestly think they‚Äôre the most ‚Äúhuman‚Äù characters ms. cathy g molina has created yet other than popoy and basha, which is already an impressive feat considering how one more chance and ESPECIALLY a second chance depicted the feeling of inadequacy in both marriage and your career.knowing that your s/o could do SO much better than you and it‚Äôs just agonizing to watch popoy slowly antagonize the woman he loves as he gets consumed by his own insecurities while basha‚Äôs doing her best to fix the damage that‚Äôs been donebut anyways to anyone who hasn‚Äôt watched the hows of us AND a second chance, 10/10 movies, both tear-jerkers, filipinos are the masters of romance-dramas idc if i‚Äôm biased, yes this review is just me singing praises for the director‚Äôs writing but ü´°

Strictly speaking, probably the best of the Kathniel movies. The one where both put in their most rounded performances, both charming and weighty when necessary. Beyond that, they're supported by much better material than in any of their other films. So much feels authentic and even the silliness of the core concept (dividing a house in half out of spite) feels grounded in a strong emotional reality that it passes by without much resistance from myself. There's also just a lot of interesting visual ideas going on here. Not all of them land perfectly, but I find myself appreciating all of them. In all her best work, Cathy Garcia-Molina has this very strong eye for divisions and framing and how that relates to the characters on screen. Obviously the divided house concept gives her a lot of chance to play with these ideas and generally speaking, they work to the film's benefit more than they detract.Where the film suffers is where it has to bow to the studio tentpole formula. Lengthy travel sequences get included in films like this as a means for the intended audience to live vicariously through the characters. Can't afford to go to The Netherlands? You can at least watch your favorite romcom team go instead. The Netherlands is a beautiful country but the entire subplot around Kathryn's brother and long lost father is just bloat that detracts from the heart of the movie. If this film had simply been contented being a romantic comedy (leaning towards drama), it might have been great. The addition of the family drama weighs it down dreadfully.That being said, it's a good movie. Too much of it works and those first two acts are some of the best I've seen from Filipino mainstream studio films. The crown jewel of the Kathniel canon, yet to be topped.

just chose to review this to reveal my unpopular opinion on this that primo and george should not have ended up together by the end of this movie.don‚Äôt get me wrong, its a GREAT movie. i loved it. but realistically i imagined that they wouldn‚Äôt get back together yet they did. although yes, their happy ending was nice to see, and i personally enjoyed the movie all throughout, an alternative where they remain out of a romantic relationship would have been an interesting plot to see.

‚ÄúWhat will be the consequences if I get back with you again? My world will stop again for you? How many years of my life will I waste again?(‚Ä¶) Look at me. Still trying to put my life back and regain everything I lost when you left me.‚Äù‚ÄúAnd what makes that sorry different from all your sorrys before? I gave you almost seven years of my life, Primo. And in those seven years, it was just one time I told you I was tired. Only once did I ask myself if I could still fight. Only once did I have the courage to tell you how I felt. That I was hurting, that I was losing myself. Just one time, in the many times I could have given up, but I didn‚Äôt. But then you only needed one time to give up on us. To leave and not come back. I needed you to fight for us that night.‚Äù

darren and his subplot ruined itfirst half of the film >>> because the second half (the amsterdam arc, specifically) seemed like a different movie.if the amsterdam arc focused more on primo's side (as the film was told from george's point-of-view), rather than the search for george and yohan's father (darren's subplot), the film would be much better and the ending could be ‚Äòmore justified.‚Äôthe only part of that arc that i like is the flower field scene. seeing the tulips was primo's and george's dream together. but things didn't go as planned. same as with life, you don't always get what you wished for but life will always find a way to give you something better or in their case, they became better persons despite the fact that they were unable to reach their dreams together as they had planned.speaking of the flower field scene, i truly wish they had given primo's side equal attention. i believe many viewers failed to notice his depression and suicidal phase. of course, it won't excuse him for what he did, but at least it shows that he didn't do it just because he wants to.overall, thou has lots of iconic lines that became part of philippine pop culture. also one of kathniel's best acting performances‚Äîdaniel's quiet moments (internal) and kathryn's intense dialogues (external). if not for darren's irrelevant subplot, this will dethrone ‚Äòshe's dating the gangster‚Äô as my favorite kathniel film. one of the highest grossing filipino films of all time, without a doubt.‚ÄúPalibhasa kasi alam na alam mo kung paano ako kunin e. Isang ngiti, isang kanta, isang yakap, isang sorry, wala... Umiikot na ulit ‚Äòyong mundo ko. Tangina, Primo! Matalino akong tao e. Pero pagdating sayo, ewan ko natatanga ako.‚Äù

Rewatching "The How's of Us," a film I once thought was close to perfect, I realize that my initial enjoyment for this film might have been misplaced.I used to think that this film was one of the more polished and masterfully written script, but my recent viewing revealed shortcomings that I just couldn't overlook.Beyond the cheesy dialogue, I found that many of the story points did not entirely make sense. The narrative, at times, felt forced, just to check off the boxes of what makes a tear-jerking romance drama film.This rewatch honestly left me disappointed, as I had expected more from a film I once held in high regard.

Heartbroken‚Ä¶just heartbroken. I hope the break-up news isn‚Äôt true. I truly hope this wasn‚Äôt their last movie together. Kathniel movies are the reason I went back to school to pursue film. Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla are inspirations to me. These movies mean so much to me. This couple means the world to me. I‚Äôve been beyond devastated after hearing the heavy rumors of the break-up and it really seems to be true. My heart seriously aches so much‚Ä¶I cannot take it. üíîWith the new drama surrounding Kathniel, it can be said that ‚ÄúThe Hows of Us‚Äù is a reflection of real life. Growing apart‚Ä¶making mistakes‚Ä¶the difficulty to forgive in adulthood‚Ä¶too many factors that limit our happiness‚Ä¶too many factors that change the way we love. üò≠üò≠üò≠The first time I watched this a couple of years ago, I was sobbing at the end of the movie. I was already a huge Kathniel fan before I watched this one, so that ending struck me so hard. Overall, the drama, cinematography and music meshes well together. I believe this is seriously a really beautiful film. I love this movie so much. I love Kathniel so much. üò≠üò≠üò≠I will always love Kathniel. As much as I would hope that they aren‚Äôt broken up, it‚Äôs not up to me to decide what‚Äôs best for them. They have helped me get through rough times. I believed in true love because of them. Sometimes, even the best relationships grow apart. Thank you Kathryn Bernardo. Thank you Daniel Padilla. Thank you for being the greatest love team of all time. I will always have a place in my heart for Kathniel. ‚ù§Ô∏è#KathnielForever

George is so Anino by UDD coded.‚Äúhindi tayo mapapakain ng passion na yan‚Äù that line literally hit me. i believe na if you really want to pursue your passion in arts or music, you shouldnt start a family or have a partner that wants to pursue something else. esp pag di naman stable pagkikita mo ng pera. its selfish. kasi di ka naman makakapag provide para sa kanila. ta mo tatay ko tangina musikero, eh wala ngang ambag sa buhay namin. physically there, but financially and emotionally absent. i really want to pursue arts since ayoko naman magka anak. pero may pamilya parin akong kailangang pakainin, ako inaasahang breadwinner, eh.pursuing your passion is truly a privilege, especially in this country with a fuck ass economy. i wish there were more opportunities for artists here in the philippines.tsaka if u wanna pursue your passion, kailangan yung partner mo wants the same future. eh si george at primo hindi talaga compatible. maganda nang maghiwalay na talaga sila kasi they want different futures. relationships should be a give and take. ano ba naiambag ni primo kay george nung una? he was selfish and doesnt know how to prioritize bigger things. he was being irrational. kahit sa bandmate nya, parang di nya pa kayang intindihin kabanda nyang gustong mag hanap ng trabaho para makapag provide sa pamilya nya. dapat nag jowa nalang si primo ng gusto rin mag pursue ng music eh, someone who wants to take the same path in life as him. and if i were george, naghanap nalang ako ng iba, o kaya just stayed single. basta wag nang ibalik yang primo na yan sa buhay ko. id just wish he changed for the better, id wish him all the best, and i hope to never hear about it.

Baka naaawa lang ako kay Kathryn ngayon kasi look at the date diba... Pero tbh binuhat nila silang lahat, kahit yung wig ni Daniel.Noong nakita ko ito nung 2018, over yung acting niya for me. Sa ikalawang panunuod, may mga mahahalagang performances si Kathryn dito. Mistulang siya ang nakaintindi sa paghihirap at ang naaangkop na kalakasan ni George upang makamit nya ang maayos na buhay.Naway ito na sana ang wakas ng pagdusa ng isang storya, ng pagbuo ng karakter sa pinoy romcoms, para lang mapunan ang negosyo ng love teams.Mas mahusay rin sana ang maiaambag sa kamalayan kung hindi na nagkatuluyan pa si Primo at George. Kay tagal rin niyang nagdusa sa makasariling pag-iisip ni Primo. Naway maging mas malaya pa ang mga ganitong kwento, hindi nahahanay sa "Prince Charming" si Maria Clara.Ang sabi ni George, pagod na sya sa grand gestures. Pagod na syang itigil yung mundo niya para kay Primo. Pero sa dulo, malalaking gestures nanaman, may pa-kanta kanta pa. Siyempre isasama niyo siya sa Amsterdam dahil siya nagbayad ng plane tickets. Walang respeto sa hiling ni George na lumayo na siya sa buhay niya. Dahil dito hindi nagsucceed ang pelikula.
